message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Observer-Based Neuro-Adaptive Optimized Control of Strict-Feedback Nonlinear Systems With State Constraints
Paper Abstract: This article proposes an adaptive neural network (NN) output feedback optimized control design for a class of strict-feedback nonlinear systems that contain unknown internal dynamics and the states that are immeasurable and constrained within some predefined compact sets. NNs are used to approximate the unknown internal dynamics, and an adaptive NN state observer is developed to estimate the immeasurable states. By constructing a barrier type of optimal cost functions for subsystems and employing an observer and the actor-critic architecture, the virtual and actual optimal controllers are developed under the framework of backstepping technique. In addition to ensuring the boundedness of all closed-loop signals, the proposed strategy can also guarantee that system states are confined within some preselected compact sets all the time. This is achieved by means of barrier Lyapunov functions which have been successfully applied to various kinds of nonlinear systems such as strict-feedback and pure-feedback dynamics. Besides, our developed optimal controller requires less conditions on system dynamics than some existing approaches concerning optimal control. The effectiveness of the proposed optimal control approach is eventually validated by numerical as well as practical examples.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Search Results for "Artificial Neural Network"

I've completed a web search for artificial neural networks. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Structure

An artificial neural network (ANN) is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks.(no content)A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.

### How They Work

Each artificial neuron receives signals from connected neurons, then processes them and sends a signal to other connected neurons, with the "signal" being a real number computed by some non-linear function of the totality of its inputs, called the activation function.(no content)The strength of the signal at each connection is determined by a weight, which adjusts during the learning process.

### Applications

Artificial neural networks are used for various tasks, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, and solving problems in artificial intelligence. They can learn from experience, and can derive conclusions from a complex and seemingly unrelated set of information.

### Training

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.

The search results contain comprehensive information about neural network architecture, history, types, and applications in machine learning.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Nonlinear control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Describing function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Describing_function"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of nonlinear control systems:

## Definition

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.

## Key Differences from Linear Systems

Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle, and it applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.(no content)These systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations, and the mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.

## Analysis Techniques

Mathematical techniques for nonlinear systems include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions. Additionally, nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Example

A thermostat-controlled heating system is an example of a nonlinear control system. A building heating system such as a furnace has a nonlinear response to changes in temperature; it is either "on" or "off". The furnace is off until the temperature falls below the "turn on" setpoint, when it turns on, and turns off when temperature reaches the "turn off" setpoint.

## Control Design Techniques

Feedback linearization is a common strategy employed in nonlinear control to control nonlinear systems, involving transforming a nonlinear control system into an equivalent linear control system through a change of variables and a suitable control input.

Links: [{"title":"Actor-critic algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actor-critic_algorithm"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Distributional Soft Actor Critic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributional_Soft_Actor_Critic"},{"title":"A2C - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A2C"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Category:Machine learning algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Machine_learning_algorithms"},{"title":"Feedback neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reflection_(artificial_intelligence)"}]

Here are the search results for "Actor-critic reinforcement learning":

## Overview

Actor-critic methods can be understood as an improvement over pure policy gradient methods like REINFORCE via introducing a baseline.(no content)Many actor-critic methods belong to the class of generalized policy iteration algorithms.

## How It Works

Since the functions used in actor-critic methods depend on the actor, the critic must learn alongside the actor.(no content)The critic is learned by value-based RL algorithms, and if the critic is estimating the state-value function, then it can be learned by any value function approximation method.

## Popular Variants

Mainstream model-free RL algorithms include Asynchronous Advantage Actor-Critic (A3C), and Soft Actor-Critic (SAC).(no content)Asynchronous Advantage Actor-Critic (A3C) is a parallel and asynchronous version of A2C, while Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) incorporates entropy maximization for improved exploration.

## Performance and Applications

In recent years, actor–critic methods have been proposed and performed well on various problems.

Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Control reversal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reversal"},{"title":"Take back control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Take_Back_Control"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

## Backstepping Control - Search Results

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about backstepping control:

### Overview

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)It is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

### How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

### Applications and Context

Backstepping is one of several nonlinear control techniques, along with feedback linearization and sliding mode control, that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.(no content)Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control, especially the backstepping stabilization method.

The method is particularly useful for controlling complex nonlinear systems that are difficult to stabilize using traditional linear control techniques.

## Backstepping Control - Search Results

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about backstepping control:

### Overview

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)It is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

### How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

### Applications and Context

Backstepping is one of several nonlinear control techniques, along with feedback linearization and sliding mode control, that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory.(no content)Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in the areas of adaptive control, singular perturbation techniques, and nonlinear control, especially the backstepping stabilization method.

The method is particularly useful for controlling complex nonlinear systems that are difficult to stabilize using traditional linear control techniques.

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"},{"title":"Orbital stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orbital_stability"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **Lyapunov stability**:

## Definition and Core Concept

Near a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable, the system remains stable under small disturbances. More specifically, Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough.

## Historical Background

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

## Related Concepts

**Asymptotic Stability**: Asymptotic stability means that solutions that start close enough not only remain close enough but also eventually converge to the equilibrium.

**Lyapunov Functions**: In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## Modern Applications

The "Second Method of Lyapunov" was found to be applicable to the stability of aerospace guidance systems which typically contain strong nonlinearities.(no content)The concept of the Lyapunov exponent has received wide interest in connection with chaos theory.

Web search results for query: "State observer control theory"

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_(controls)"},{"title":"Talk:State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:State_observer"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"Linear–quadratic–Gaussian control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear–quadratic–Gaussian_control"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about state observer control theory:

## Overview

In control theory, a state observer (also called a state estimator or Luenberger observer) is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

## Why State Observers Are Needed

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

## Key Principles

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.(no content)A separation principle states that under some assumptions the problem of designing an optimal feedback controller for a stochastic system can be solved by designing an optimal observer for the state of the system, which feeds into an optimal deterministic controller for the system. Thus the problem can be broken into two separate parts, which facilitates the design.

## Observer Types

Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

Links: [{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control"},{"title":"Pseudospectral optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pseudospectral_optimal_control"},{"title":"Control (optimal control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_(optimal_control_theory)"},{"title":"Unscented optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unscented_optimal_control"},{"title":"Stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_control"},{"title":"Machine learning control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_control"},{"title":"Coherent control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coherent_control"},{"title":"H-infinity methods in control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H-infinity_methods_in_control_theory"},{"title":"PROPT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PROPT"},{"title":"Witsenhausen's counterexample - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Witsenhausen's_counterexample"}]

## Optimal Control

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of optimal control:

### Definition and Core Concept

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.

### Key Characteristics

Optimal control deals with the problem of finding a control law for a given system such that a certain optimality criterion is achieved. A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.

### Applications

It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research. Examples include a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, with the objective to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure, and a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment through fiscal and monetary policy.

### Mathematical Methods

The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).(no content)The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s.

### Historical Context

The theory has evolved significantly and now includes specialized variants such as stochastic control, pseudospectral methods, and machine learning approaches for solving complex optimal control problems.

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of optimal control:

### Definition and Core Concept

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.

### Key Characteristics

Optimal control deals with the problem of finding a control law for a given system such that a certain optimality criterion is achieved. A control problem includes a cost functional that is a function of state and control variables. An optimal control is a set of differential equations describing the paths of the control variables that minimize the cost function.

### Applications

It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research. Examples include a spacecraft with controls corresponding to rocket thrusters, with the objective to reach the Moon with minimum fuel expenditure, and a nation's economy, with the objective to minimize unemployment through fiscal and monetary policy.

### Mathematical Methods

The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).(no content)The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s.

### Historical Context

The theory has evolved significantly and now includes specialized variants such as stochastic control, pseudospectral methods, and machine learning approaches for solving complex optimal control problems.

Links: [{"title":"Adaptive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control"},{"title":"Adaptive cruise control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_cruise_control"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Self-tuning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-tuning"},{"title":"Adaptive traffic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_traffic_control"},{"title":"Continuous monitoring and adaptive control (stormwater management) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_monitoring_and_adaptive_control_(stormwater_management)"},{"title":"Xbox Adaptive Controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xbox_Adaptive_Controller#:~:text=The co-creator of the,much they could be ..."},{"title":"Real-time adaptive security - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Real-time_adaptive_security"},{"title":"File:Xbox Adaptive Controller V&A.JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Xbox_Adaptive_Controller_V&A.JPG"},{"title":"Adaptive autonomy","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_autonomy"}]

Here are the results from the web search for "Adaptive control":

## Overview

Adaptive control is the control method used by a controller which must adapt to a controlled system with parameters which vary, or are initially uncertain.(no content)For example, as an aircraft flies, its mass will slowly decrease as a result of fuel consumption; a control law is needed that adapts itself to such changing conditions.

## Key Differences

Adaptive control is different from robust control in that it does not need a priori information about the bounds on these uncertain or time-varying parameters; robust control guarantees that if the changes are within given bounds the control law need not be changed, while adaptive control is concerned with control law changing itself.

## Foundations and Methods

The foundation of adaptive control is parameter estimation, which is a branch of system identification. Common methods of estimation include recursive least squares and gradient descent.

## Types of Adaptive Control

Broad categories of feedback adaptive control include Model reference adaptive controllers (MRACs) that incorporate a reference model defining desired closed loop performance, and Model identification adaptive controllers (MIACs) that perform system identification while the system is running.

## Applications

A particularly successful application of adaptive control has been adaptive flight control, which has focused on guaranteeing stability of a model reference adaptive control scheme using Lyapunov arguments.

The search also returned information about specific applications like adaptive cruise control for vehicles, adaptive traffic control systems, and adaptive security systems, which all employ adaptive control principles in their respective domains.

Web search results for query: "Feedback control systems"

Links: [{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback"},{"title":"Sensitivity (control systems) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_(control_systems)"},{"title":"Linear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_control"},{"title":"Control system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_system"},{"title":"Plant (control theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plant_(control_theory)"},{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Cybernetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cybernetics"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about feedback control systems:

## Overview

A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system.(no content)Its name comes from the information path in the system: process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

## Key Components

In the case of linear feedback systems, a control loop including sensors, control algorithms, and actuators is arranged in an attempt to regulate a variable at a setpoint (SP).(no content)The controller monitors the controlled process variable (PV), and compares it with the reference or set point (SP). The difference between actual and desired value of the process variable, called the error signal, or SP-PV error, is applied as feedback to generate a control action to bring the controlled process variable to the same value as the set point.

## Advantages Over Open-Loop Systems

Control systems that include some sensing of the results they are trying to achieve are making use of feedback and can adapt to varying circumstances to some extent. Open-loop control systems do not make use of feedback, and run only in pre-arranged ways.(no content)Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection (such as hills in the cruise control example above) guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties, when the model structure does not match perfectly the real process and the model parameters are not exact.

## Common Example

An everyday example is the cruise control on a road vehicle; where external influences such as hills would cause speed changes, and the driver has the ability to alter the desired set speed. The PID algorithm in the controller restores the actual speed to the desired speed in an optimum way, with minimal delay or overshoot, by controlling the power output of the vehicle's engine.

## Common Controller Types

A common closed-loop controller architecture is the PID controller.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Findings:**
The paper proposes a novel adaptive neural network-based optimal control design for strict-feedback nonlinear systems with state constraints. I identified and validated 8 key technologies and methodologies:

| Entity | Type | Relation | Purpose |
|--------|------|----------|---------|
| Neural Network (Machine Learning) | Method | Uses | Approximates unknown internal dynamics |
| Adaptive Control | Method | Uses | Core technique for uncertain system parameters |
| State Observer | Method | Uses | Estimates immeasurable states |
| Nonlinear Control | Task | Uses | Control problem class being addressed |
| Lyapunov Function | Method | Uses | Ensures stability and state constraints |
| Actor-Critic Algorithm | Method | Uses | Architecture for optimal controllers |
| Backstepping | Method | Uses | Control design framework |
| Optimal Control | Task | Proposes | Novel observer-based neuro-adaptive design |

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed
- Paper type: contribution
- 8 triples identified
- 6 methods and 2 tasks
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and valid

The analysis shows this paper combines classical control theory techniques (backstepping, Lyapunov stability) with modern machine learning (neural networks, actor-critic) to solve a challenging problem in nonlinear control systems.

Sources:
- [Neural network (machine learning)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning))
- [Adaptive control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_control)
- [State observer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer)
- [Nonlinear control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control)
